review.title: On the Complexity of Semantic Integration of OWL Ontologies
review.abstract: We propose a new mechanism for integration of OWL ontologies using semantic import relations. In contrast to the standard OWL importing, we do not require all axioms of the imported ontologies to be taken into account for reasoning tasks, but only their logical implications over a chosen signature. This property comes natural in many ontology integration scenarios, especially when the number of ontologies is large. In this paper, we study the complexity of reasoning over ontologies with semantic import relations and establish a range of tight complexity bounds for various fragments of OWL.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction and Motivation
sections.text: Logical ontology languages such as OWL and OWL 2 [Cuenca Grau et al., 2008] are becoming increasingly popular means of representation, integration and retrieval of information, especially in the life sciences, such as biology and medicine. For example, an Open Biological and Biomedical Ontology Repository [Smith et al., 2007] comprises more than eighty specialized ontologies on topics as diverse as molecular functions, biological processes and cellular components. Ontology integration aims in particular to organize information across different domains in a modular manner so that information from one ontology can be reused in other ontologies. For example, the ontology of diseases can describe anatomical structures to describe the location of diseases, or genes with which diseases are corrected.Integration of multiple ontologies in OWL: an OWL ontology can refer to one or more other otologies.

sections.heading: 9 Conclusions
sections.text: We have introduced a new mechanism for ontology integration, based on semantic import relations between ontologies, which represents a generalization of the standard OWL import. In order to import an external ontology O into a local one, one must define an import relationship that defines a set of symbols whose semantics should be borrowed from O. The significant feature of the proposed mechanism, which is natural in complex ontological integration scenarios, is that each ontology has its own view of ontologies, which it refines and views of the same ontology are independent unless they are coordinated by import relationships. We have shown that this feature can lead to an exponential increase in the temporal complexity of the argument about ontologies combined with acyclic import relations. Intuitively, this is the reason why one must look at several views of the same ontology, each of which has a different ontology.
